result.execSummary:
The defendant Lisa M Pfaff was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver THC (<=200g), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(h)1.
  • Possession of THC, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).
  • Possess Drug Paraphernalia, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.573(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Court costs waived.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.

Defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol and other drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known illegal drug users or dealers.

Must comply with any other recommendations of your probation agent.

Must submit a DNA sample at the Jackson County Jail and pay the surcharge.

records.addlTxt:
Due to COVID19 pandemic the following participants are appearing by video/phone by Zoom:    Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek, defendant, Attorney Roush, Judge, Court reporter, Clerk.  Defendant plead guilty to Count 2 in 19CF209.  Remaining counts in that case are dismissed but read in for sentencing purposes.  Court ordered 19TR3640 reopened and dismissed.   Court reviewed the elements and potential penalties of the charge the defendant plead to.  She understood.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant. She understood. Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea. Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered her plea and waived her constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of OAR contrary to 343.44(1)(b).  Joint recommendation for:  1 year probation on each case.  Request the court costs be waived.  Defendant did not exercise her right to allocution.

Court ordered sentence withheld, 1 year probation each case, concurrent.  CC waived.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Sentencing hearing on August 7, 2020 at 08:30 am.  In order to protect the health of the public and individuals who work in the court system and to ensure social distancing, this court hearing is being held remotely in accordance with the recommendations contained in the final report of the Chief Justices Wisconsin Courts COVID-19 Task Force.

Join Zoom Hearing by Web from your computer, tablet or smartphone:

https://wicourts.zoom.us/j/95249012820?pwd=MXQxQ25MUTV4c0thS09FeUh0UFhQdz09

Meeting ID: 952 4901 2820

Password:  798997

Join Zoom Hearing by phone:
1- 312-626-6799 
Meeting ID: 952 4901 2820
Find your local number: https://wicourts.zoom.us/u/acvSsasmMU

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State. Defenant appeared in person with Atty Sebion appearing specially for Atty Rousch. Set for sentencing hearing 15CF162. Judges JA will contact Attys for plea/sentencing hearing dates in both cases 15CF162 and 19CF209.
Status conference on March 6, 2020 at 02:30 pm.

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appears in person with Counsel James Ritland.  Amanda Roush.  

19CF209 - Arraignment:  Defense waives reading of the Information and enters NGP's to all counts.  Court reviews charges and potential penalties.  Court enters NGP's to all 3 counts.  Attorney Roush states she has received an offer from DA Diehn so requests a status conference date.

15CF162:  Motion to revoke DPA.  Defendant is contesting the revocation of diversion agreement.  Court places call to Pat Bell, sworn, testifies.  ADA Hynek questions Mr. Bell.  He supervises the diversion requirements.  She has not completed community service and has new criminal charges.  She has not turned in any completed community service which 50 hours were to be completed within the first 6 months.  That time period passed some time ago.  Attorney Roush questions Mr. Bell.  Defendant has completed 2 requirements of the diversion.  He is aware she has transportation issues.  No re-direct or further evidence.

ADA Hynek requests the DPA be revoked.  Defense requests the diversion be continued and states her argument.  Court orders the diversion agreement will be revoked on 15CF162.  She is now convicted of Count 1 but will be continued on bond and continue to track with 19CCF209.   Status conference on March 6 at 2:30.

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Roush.  She hasn't done community service.  State says defendant should make the community service a priority.  Set another STC in 2020.

Defendant appears in person with counsel Amanda Roush.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Attorney Roush states that she is going to be working on her 50 hours of community service.  Working on getting driver's license back.  ADA Hynek makes statement to the Court.  AODA assessment is done and she needs to do the mental health assessment yet.  She has an appointment in February as she was waiting for insurance coverage.

Will schedule for review in 90 days.
Review Hearing - Diversion Agreement September 13, 2019 at 10:00 a.m.

District Attorney Daniel S. Diehn appeared on behalf of the State.  SPD Emily Roush appears on behalf of defendant.  She states why her client isn't here; her ride's car broke down this morning.  She's been making progress with the diversion agreement.  Attorney Roush requests a warrant not be issued.  Defendant is still trying to get here while the Judge is here today.  DA Diehn verifies she is making progress working with the diversion coordinator.  Will leave the issuance of a warrant up to the Court.  
Court will not issue a warrant at this time.  If she gets here today, will hear the case.  If not, will set out 90 days for a review.

L. P. called about 8:35 a.m. to inform court that the person she was getting a ride from - their car over heated, but L. P. is using her neighbor's phone to call us. ?I did not ask her how she knew that her ride's car over heated if she has to use her neighbor's phone. She stated she would not be able to come to court - transfered call to JA
Review Hearing - Diversion Agreement on June 21, 2019 at 9:15 a.m.

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appears in person with counsel SPD Amanda Roush.  ADA Hynek gives the Court an update regarding information from Mr. Bell.  Attorney Roush states she has spoken to him as well.  Has an appointment scheduled with him for 3/18/19 and wishes to continue working with Mr. Bell.  Court reviews potential penalties and possiblity of prison or jail if the diversion agreement isn't successfully completed.  

Will be set for status in 60 days and will be scheduled through J.A.

Defendant appeared in person with counsel SPD Amanda Roush.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Continuation of Motion to Revoke Diversion Agreement.  Defense had objected at last hearing.  Court states the history of that last hearing.  Attorney Roush states that she has now been following through with Pat Bell as of September, has completed AODA assessment, and has a meeting with Mr. Bell in January.  Also looking for a provider to do a mental health assessment that is acceptable with her insurance.  ADA Hynek states she has recently talked to Mr. Bell as well and the State rescinds it's motion to revoke.

Defendant appears in person with counsel SPD Amanda Roush.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Motion to revoke diversion agreement filed by the State.  Attorney Roush states they are contesting the revocation of the diversion agreement and makes her argument.  The case in LaCrosse County was before the diversion agreement was in place.  She's had phone difficulties and has made contact by phone and by mail with Pat Bell.  She has also started counseling.  State makes statement to the Court.

Court will adjourn the motion and will have his J.A. reschedule in the future and expects at that time she will be engaging with Mr. Bell and living up to her promises in the agreement.
Post-Plea Agreement on Count 1

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appears in person with counsel SPD Travis Satorius.  Will plea to 15CF162 - Counts 1, 3, 4. Count 1 will be a post-plea diversion agreement and Counts 3 & 4 will be probation.  Will also dispose of 16CF175 today.  State is in compliance with victim notification.

Court reviews charges and potential penalties of both cases.  Will amend Count 1 in 16CF175 to a misdemeanor bailjumping.  15CF162, Count 1 - No contest plea; Count 3 - No contest, Count 4 - No contest.  Reviewed elements.

16CF175 - Amended Ct 1 - No contest, Count 2 - No contest, Count 3 - No contest.  Court performs plea colloquy/waiver of rights.  Attorney Satorius states the elements attached are only for 15CF162 but Attorney Satorius states they have discussed the elements of 16CF175.  Elements reviewed.  Plea/waiver of rights colloquy performed.  Defense stipulates to facts in both cases to support the pleas.  Court finds she understands the proceedings, waives her rights and enters her pleas; finds a factual basis exists for pleas.  Findings of guilty in 15CF162:  Count 3, & Count 4. Count 2 is dismissed and read-in for sentencing.  Count is 1 is deferred.  16CF175:  Accepts pleas to Counts 1, 2, 3 and is found guilty.

State requests the Court accept the agreement in the Statmeent ot Negotiated Plea for 3 years probation.  Deferred Prosecution Agreement is presented to the Court.  Defense counsel makes statement to the court regarding sentencing.  Defendant excercises her right to allocution.  

Court accepts the diversion agreement in 15CFR162, Count 1.  All other counts in both cases Court places on probation for 3 years with conditions:  Must undergo an AODA assessment and comply with any recomendations for programming/counseling.  Must comply with any other recommendations made by agent.  Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.  Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known illegal drug users or dealers. No jail credit.  Must pay the costs and must submit a DNA and pay the surcharges.
Subpoena served on G.R. to appear at jury trial
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on April 13, 2018 for the jury trial
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on S.B. to appear on April 13, 2018 for the jury trial
Mary called from Judge Goodman's office.  There will be a plea on 4-13 at 9 a.m. and the trial is off.

Defendant does not appear with counsel SPD Travis Satorius.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appears on behalf of the State.  Attorney Satorius states he hasn't contact with his client for quite some time.  A proposal in the last 48 hours is what his client will accept.  The State asks the trial come off and that agreement is correct.  Court will change to plea/sentencing on the trial date, 4

Back on the record at 8:42 as defendant is now present with her counsel after they had some discussion.  Attorney Satorius states his client still wants to go to trial.  ADA Hynek and Attorney Satorius leave courtroom for discussion.  Back on record.  Joint request for until end of the day to notify the office regarding their agreement.  Request is granted.  Will either be a plea or trial on the 13th.  Trial will remain on at this time.
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on M.K. to appear on April 13, 2018 at the jury trial.

Defendant appears in person with attorney Karleigh Miller appearing specially for attorney Cohen, by phone.  Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant makes a statement to the Court. She is to go to SPDO by close of business on December 19 and if denied to petition for Court appointed attorney.

Court sets for a Motion Hearing on 12-16-16 at 1:45 p.m.  Attorney Cohen will need to file a motion to withdraw prior to the hearing date.

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and without counsel.   Defendant says she is attempting to hire an attorney.  She is not going to follow through with SPD.  Court questioned when she will have counsel.  Court says she needs legal representation.  Defendant wants to move forward.  Court will not allow her to represent herself.  Serious charges.  Need to retain counsel immediatly.  Adjourned to 12/21.  MUST BRING AN ATTORNEY!!!!!!
